description: H3 hexagon grid cells representing agricultural field data with soil nutrient levels and application recommendations

columns.name: h3_index
columns.notes: Required in SELECT for map highlighting.

columns.name: field_name
columns.description: Name identifier for the agricultural field
columns.notes: Use for grouping and comparing across fields

columns.name: area
columns.description: The area of ground the hex takes up.

columns.name: yield_target
columns.description: The farmer's intended yield goal for the hexagon
columns.notes: Higher values indicate areas with better yield potential. Common targets are 175 bu/ac for lower productivity areas and 240 bu/ac for high productivity zones.

columns.name: P_in_soil
columns.notes: Phosphorus is critical for root development and energy transfer. Low P soils require supplemental fertilizer.

columns.name: K_in_soil
columns.notes: Potassium helps with disease resistance and water regulation. Essential for overall plant health.

columns.name: N_in_soil
columns.notes: Nitrogen is typically very low in soil tests as it's highly mobile. Most N comes from fertilizer application.

columns.name: calcium
columns.notes: Calcium is important in soil because it strengthens plant cell walls, promotes root and shoot growth, and is essential for improving soil structure (aggregation and permeability)

columns.name: magnesium
columns.notes: An essential secondary nutrient, a critical component of the chlorophyll molecule required for photosynthesis in plants.

columns.name: cec
columns.description: Current CEC (Cation Exchange Capacity) level in soil
columns.notes: Measure of a soil's ability to hold and supply positively charged nutrient ions (cations) like potassium, calcium, and magnesium, thereby serving as a reservoir for plant nutrition.

columns.name: pH
columns.description: The acidity or alkalinity of the soil
columns.notes: Expressed on a scale from 0 to 14, and fundamentally dictates the availability of nutrients to the plant.

columns.name: N_to_apply
columns.notes: Application rate based on yield target and soil test. Higher yield targets require more N.

columns.name: P_to_apply
columns.notes: Calculated based on soil test levels. Areas with low P_in_soil will have higher P_to_apply values.

columns.name: K_to_apply
columns.notes: Based on soil K levels and crop removal rates. Zero application when K_in_soil is adequate.

columns.name: geometry
columns.description: Spatial polygon representing the hexagon boundary
columns.notes: Use for spatial queries, distance calculations, and area computations with DuckDB spatial functions.

query_hints: When asked about 'low' nutrients, use the thresholds defined above
When asked about 'needs' or 'requires' fertilizer, look at the *_to_apply columns
For cost calculations, users typically refer to fertilizer application amounts
When comparing fields, GROUP BY field_name
When asked about 'problem areas' or 'attention needed', look for low nutrient levels or high application requirements
domain_knowledge: Corn typically requires 1.0 lb N per bushel of grain produced
Phosphorus fertilizer prices vary but average $0.3465 per lb P
Potassium fertilizer prices average $0.202 per lb K2O
Nitrogen fertilizer prices average $0.45-0.65 per lb N
Variable rate application saves money by only applying where needed
You should apply lime to a part of the field where calcium levels are low, and pH is low.
